hero.title: Campus Balboa
hero.description: A <important>nonprofit</important> entirely <important>dedicated</important> to <important>fostering balboa growth</important> and <important>excellence</important> in and around <important>Montreal</important>.

development.title: Develop and sustain
development.content: To be an independent entity aimed at the development and sustainability of the Balboa community in Montreal and its surrounding areas.

practice.title: Encourage the dance
practice.content: Encourage the practice of Balboa dance in Montreal and its surrounding areas

excellence.title: Foster excellence
excellence.content: Foster and promote the quality and excellence of activities related to Balboa in Montreal and its surroundings

support.title: Support initiatives
support.content: Support and promote initiatives and activities related to Balboa in Montreal and its surrounding areas

organize.title: Organize activities
organize.content: Organize and support of Balboa-related activities aimed at visibility and increase of the Balboa scene in Montreal and its surroundings

knowledge.title: Share knowledge
knowledge.content: Bring together balboa dancers in Montreal and its surrounding areas with a common goal of sharing knowledge

felix.name: Félix
felix.title: President
felix.bio: Félix has been an avid balboa dancer since 2014 and has taught at Cat’s Corner since 2016. The Montreal balboa scene is close to his heart, and he is behind several initiatives and events. A swing music lover, he can often be found behind the DJ booth at local dances.

tania.name: Tania
tania.title: Vice-President
tania.bio: Tania has been a fan of balboa since 2013 and has taught at Studio 88 Swing since 2016. Scientific in nature, she stands out for her analytical and technical approach. Despite these more discreet attributes, it remains very easy to find Tania on the dance floor by following the echo of her bursts of laughter.

sara.name: Sara
sara.title: Treasurer
sara.bio: Sara, a balboa enthusiast since 2003, is part of the Thé Dansant Montréal organization. An adventurer, she frequently participates in faraway balboa events during which she strives to discover as many new people she has never danced with as she can.

sihem.name: Sihem
sihem.title: Secretary
sihem.bio: Sihem has been dancing balboa since 2015 and can be found on every dance floor in the city. She particularly appreciates balboa for its elegance and for the complexity of its connection. Her playful and unifying sides make her a strong steal jams participant.

cara.name: Cara
cara.title: Administrator
cara.bio: Cara, a balboa dancer since 2014, is active and engaged in the Montreal scene. She teaches at Cat's Corner and is one of the organizers of Apéros Balboa Montréal. Her gentle and warm approach makes her an excellent dancer in closed position and is passionate about slow balboa and pure balboa. She also holds the prestigious title of “the last person to leave the dance floor” (undefeated).

bpm.title: Tempo
bpm.description: It is important to note that theses guidelines are entirely subjective. A great DJ will be able to determine the best choice of tempo depending on the situation, and dancers present. Variety and sense of timing is what makes an exceptional set: a set that only stays within the “sweet spot” will be boring, playing slow songs too often might kill the energy of the room, and playing too many fast songs might tire out the dancers. It is impossible to please everybody, so it is imperative that the DJ reads the room and uses their judgement.

slowBal.title: Slow balboa
slowBal.description: Slow balboa can be danced to very slow music, but dancers tend to be most comfortable around 80 BPM. Therefore, it is recommended to aim for the middle of this range rather than the extremes unless there is a lot of advanced dancers or you are playing more than one slow song in a row.

awkwardRange.title: Awkward area
awkwardRange.description: This range is considered difficult for balboa dancers since it is slightly too fast for slow balboa, and too slow for conventional balboa. It is therefore highly encouraged to avoid this range in most cases.

beginnerClass.title: Classes
beginnerClass.description: In a classroom context, it is sometimes desirable to play a bit slower to give the learners a chance to assimilate concepts.

bulk.title: Bulk of music
bulk.description: Around 80% of the music played at a social dance should be in this range. After an intro class, it is recommended to start lower, and gradually work your way up. Generally, aiming for the middle of the range rather than the extremes, and not playing too many songs in a row of similar BPM will yield best results.

comfortableArea.title: Comfortable area
comfortableArea.description: This range is generally appropriate for most level of dancers. When there are dancers of all levels in the room, the majority will be able to dance comfortably in this range.

sweetSpot.title: Sweet spot
sweetSpot.description: This small range works well for all types of balboa (pure and swing). Most advanced and intermediate dancers will be comfortable social dancing to this range. It is ideal to bring people back to the dance floor after a song that did not work too well (either too slow, fast, or other).

competitionRange.title: Competition
competitionRange.description: Internationally, tempos for finals of “open” or advanced competitions will be within this range. Sometimes all-skates will be faster and warm-ups slower.

fastTempo.title: Fast tempo
fastTempo.description: It is important to note that the more the tempo goes past 220 BPM, the less people will be comfortable dancing to the song. However, the challenge of dancing to extremely fast songs is one of the many pleasures of dancing balboa. It is not recommended to play too many extreme songs in a single social dance.

distribution.title: Distribution
distribution.description: The BPM distribution of a DJ set depends on several factors. In particular, the average level of the dancers present, the quality of the dance floor, the size of the dance floor, the energy level of the room, the timing (start of the evening, end of the evening, start of the set, end of the set), and much more. It is generally recommended to gradually increase and decrease the speed rather than going from one extreme to the other. A fast song played directly after a slow song will sound much faster in contrast, and vice versa. On the other hand, a dance floor that has little energy can benefit from a faster song. Similarly, a dance floor that's too tired for fast songs might regain some vigor after a slow song. This is why it is important to adapt to the people in the room, and every DJ will do this differently.
